slide.text: USMS University™ Quick Start Training Prospecting

slide.title: Prospecting
slide.text:
© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Getting Started
In order to be successful in any sales venture you must be a great prospector.
Without prospecting, there would be no one for you to sell to. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Prospecting is a form of marketing so it’s important to keep some marketing basics in mind when prospecting:
Have a purpose for your visit. When the prospect says: “I already have that service” or something like it, you say: “That’s exactly why I’m here!”
Remember your sales basics. Use a strong opening statement and create a favorable first impression.
Have compelling collateral materials you can leave with the prospect.
Much of prospecting is follow up.
Don’t expect to make a sale on a prospecting call. It’s always possible, however your job in prospecting is to uncover a need or interest. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. There are several ways to prospect for business:
The old fashioned door-to-door method. Believe it or not, it works very well in our industry today.
By telephone: contacting existing businesses or new ones via yellow pages, dba listings, vertical market lists, new corporations, etc.
By E-Mail.
With a web site, social media, and search engine placement.
Referral business – best of all.
Banks, franchisers, associations, POS providers and other alliances.
Direct mail to a targeted market (new business, restaurants, car dealers, etc.).
Introduction letter, call or visit to known business owners – your personal contacts.
Advertisements. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. “When you first start out, spend most of your time working on immediate business and a smaller portion of your time working on future referral sources.”
“As soon as you can cover your immediate income needs, you can increase the time you spend developing long-term business sources.” Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Effective ways to get started:
Choose vertical businesses in your area such as:
Restaurants Retailers Medical or dental practices Internet businesses Insurance companies or brokers Auto repair Auto dealers Contractors Any other business you feel comfortable with.
You can contact these merchants by phone or organize them geographically and go see them in person (recommended).
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Effective ways to get started:
Utilize leads provided by the company (if available in your area). See each prospect and contact all merchants in their vicinity by direct contact.
Contact friends, family members and prior business associates who have businesses. In addition, get lists of their friends, family members and associates as referrals and contact them too.
You should start with a list of at least 50 businesses to contact.
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Little Known Secrets:
A warm call is always better than a cold call. All one needs to make a “warm call” is a referral. The person referring does not have to be a client of yours. Any contact will do, even if you just met them. Open the door simply by saying a name of who referred you.
Lesson Learned: Everyone is a referral source Corollary: Ask everyone for referrals
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Try this: When contacting new potential prospects, whether they are interested or not, ask them for a few names of someone they recommend you contact When you contact the business they mentioned, start out with: “Hi, this is _____ with USMS. ___”John Doe” with _________ recommended I contact you about saving money (or increasing sales, or setting up a merchant account) Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Bird Dogs:
Bird dogs are your eyes and ears. The modern term is “Affiliate”. These folks help you find business, generally for a small referral fee.
Keep your Bird Dogs happy!
For each client received, give your Bird Dog cash or a gift. Send thank you cards with your referral fee or gift, and follow up by phone and ensure they’ll continue to send customers.
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Work Your Bird Dog System
When you contact a prospect, whether a potential buyer or not, always ask for referrals.
Do the following:
Get all of their contact information. Keep their contact information in a database. Send them a thank you card for considering the idea of referring business. Contact them within a week of the initial contact. Contact them at least 3-4 times per year by phone and mail. If you have the resources, it’s always a good idea to send a newsletter.
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
Prospecting for Clients and Bird Dogs:
Everyone is a prospect. Prospects contacted today may not be interested now, but are always future potential clients, weeks, months or even years later. Get each prospect’s contact information. Send a thank you card for their time. Follow up by telephone. If they’re not ready to do business, let them know you’d like to keep in contact. Put their contact information in your database and contact them periodically. Always ask for referrals- even if they aren’t a customer. The more referrals you ask for, the more you get. Stay in contact with the prospect as a prospect and a potential bird dog.
Prospecting Once you exhaust your list of friends, family, and business associates you’ll need to move on. Build a valuable referral system by combining your prospecting for referrals with prospecting for new clients as follows:

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Build your Prospect Pipeline:
Success is based on two factors: Quantity and Quality. It doesn’t matter how good a closer you are if you don’t have enough prospects. Here are some numbers you should focus on to build a large prospect base:
Potential new prospects contacted each week- 150 to 300 New warm prospects developed each week- 25 to 50 Thank you cards to new prospects each week- 25 to 50 Follow up calls/contacts each week- 50 to 100
With these volumes you’ll see large results. (If you aren’t getting results, YOU’RE NOT TALKING TO ENOUGH PROSPECTS- time to G.O.Y.A.!! Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Build a pipeline to hundreds or even thousands of potential new clients and you’ll be closing new sales every week.
If you are contacting 150 or more prospects each week consistently, and add about 30 each week to your prospecting system, in six months you’ll have over 700 potential clients.
Now suppose you close about 2% of your potential clients each month- that’s 14 new accounts per month. Now suppose each new client is worth $35 per month in new revenue (plus signing bonuses, etc.). Do the math:
35 x 14 x 12 months = $5,880 in residual monthly income after just the first year. That’s $11,880 after 2 years !!
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Maintaining contact with your prospects:
Call them, at least once per quarter and provide information that helps their business.
Send a letter or newsletter at least 4X per year that includes helpful tips on how to improve their business and how to get the most from their merchant services.
Tell them about new services that can help their business such as consumer financing, merchant cash advance or gift cards.
Inform them about new technology like wireless or IP solutions.
Have a “Bird Dog” contest with cash and prizes for referrals.
Lose touch and they forget you. Stay in touch and you’ll develop numerous prospects and referrals. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. USMS has a virtual CRM System to help you achieve prospecting success:
Best results occur when you enter all data about prospects you speak with. The more data entered, the more effectively you’ll turn prospects into clients.
Example:
You’ve entered hundreds of prospects into the system with email addresses, street addresses, fax, phone numbers, type of equipment they have, who they process with, when their contract is up, etc. 100 prospects have old terminals that become obsolete. Send emails, letters, faxes or call and notify them about the terminal. How many new sales would that help you create? Suppose USMS™ forms an alliance with a top marketing consultant for small businesses who wants to provide a free seminar. If you could invite a large database of prospects how many sales will that get you? What if you could get paid for each prospect that signs up? Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Merchants with Contracts:
When merchants are under contract first make sure you can’t save them or help them make enough money to switch. Remember that some will switch just for better service.
If it’s too costly to switch services, get the required cancellation date and note it in your follow up system (CRM).
Find out when they must notify their current provider in order to cancel. Most contracts have a roll over clause or period.
Stay in touch with them regularly.
Contact them 60 to 90 days prior to the date that must give notice and alert them when they can switch services.
In the meantime, you can always provide them with other services such as gift cards, check conversion or financing. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Let your Clients help you make the Big Score!
Many valuable referral sources will come from your clients. Clients could:
Sponsor you in to the local chamber of commerce. Be an association member or a franchisee and refer you to others or the head office. Be part of a large buying group Be part of a network marketing company Refer you to vendors that serve many businesses like theirs (vendors may need additional income sources such as referral fees) Refer you to their bank (small or community banks don’t usually handle merchant processing directly. Provide a letter of recommendation introducing you to their bank, vendors and other potential sources of business. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Sources of New Business Information:
DBA (Doing business as), aka: Fictitious name filings- County offices
Legal Newspapers-publish new business listings and maybe available on-line
State Sales Tax Administration- new tax ID Numbers- call your state
Business License Filings- city and county offices. These are hot because businesses that file them are serious about starting up
New Phone Connects- easy to contact because you have their business # Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Sources of New Business Information:
New Domain Registrations- on-line businesses.
Yellow Pages- Still a great place to find business. Look for less traditional businesses such as attorneys, doctors, insurance brokers, etc, that do not advertise that they accept cards. Traditional businesses are fine to call as well.
Magazines- magazines, periodicals, trade publications, trade newsletters, newspapers, etc. Look for display and classified ads for smaller, start ups.
Government Agencies- Small Business Administration, Minority Business Administration, Department of Corporations, etc.
Referral Sources- Chamber of Commerce, Banks, Franchisers, etc. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Contacting New Businesses
New businesses are often swamped with direct mail from many competitors. To win many of these prospects you must stand out from the crowd!:
Pick up the phone and call them.
Go see them in person.
Make 4-1-1 calls to get new business listing phone numbers when none are available with the county record. While it’s common for competitors to mail to new businesses, it’s rare for many to do this.
When you call try:
“Congratulations on your new business. I know you probably got a lot of mail for merchant services. I’d like to tell you why our company is different and how we can help grow your sales in addition to providing credit card processing.” Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Open the door with a great opening statement. When they bring up price, here’s an easy response:
“On the surface, we all look competitive. It’s the little things that make a big difference such as how we handle service, help you get more customers, educate you on how to minimize processing costs, that sort of stuff. That’s why we should meet before you make any decisions.”
Get in the door. Once you are with the client you can present many compelling reasons why they should go with you and USMS.
New businesses will establish DBAs and open a checking account to get started. Many may be difficult to contact or not be ready to discuss merchant services at this stage. Follow-up until they’re ready. They’ll usually establish a business license or phone number when they’re ready to open. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Finding the Best Businesses
While new businesses are good prospects, existing businesses everywhere are proven long lasting clients:
Value determined by history and volume.
Have a better idea of what products and services will help their business grow.
Object less to investing money for new equipment, products and services.
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Determine the best existing businesses to market to using the following criteria:
Merchant processing volume- larger volume equals larger potential savings when they switch to us or add a PIN Pad.
Large ticket merchants- more prone to need a PIN Pad and use other services such as consumer financing and check guarantee.
Less traditional businesses- less likely to be called on by competitors and may include insurance companies, churches, mobile home parks, government offices, and other non-retail type businesses.
Under served businesses- businesses less likely to be called on and are traditionally overcharged by banks and other processors.
Current processing rates- the higher the current rates, the more likely they are to switch. Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Ways to approach existing businesses:
Using PIN Debit: “Our company can show you a little known trick that reduces the cost of many transactions to less than 1%.”
Using Check Conversion: “Do you know that you can accept checks just like credit cards? The money goes electronically into your checking account and the payment is guaranteed and with no charge backs.
Merchants with old equipment: “Would you be interested in new, state of the art equipment if it was no additional cost to you?”
Accomplish this with a processing analysis and Business Analysis. Show that the overall savings and enhanced income exceeds the investment amount for new equipment.
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Ways to approach existing businesses:
Interchange Increases: “Periodically Visa and MC increase rates to service providers who pass these increases to you. Often, when this happens, the provider adds additional mark up. A simple analysis will show if your recent increases were fair or excessive.”
Use Referrals: “We helped Mr. Smith at the pharmacy save over $800 this year. He suggested we talk to you and that you may be interested in saving as well.”
Package Sale: “Our solution could help increase your bottom line by ten thousand dollars or more this year. Let me take a few minutes to show you what I’m talking about.” Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. When prospecting existing businesses pay close attention to the signs that determine what opportunities exist with that merchant:
Do they have old equipment that needs replacing?
Does equipment print the full card number- in violation of state federal laws?
Do they have a sign that says, “No Checks”?
Do they have a PIN Pad?
Who’s their current provider- when you know the competition you’ll know their general pricing. Merchants with smaller banks generally pay more. Some banks or processors are unusually high in their fees.
Is it a large ticket business in need of consumer financing?
Do they have a check reader or check imager? Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Establishing strategic referral sources is one of the keys to success. Types of sources that can provide great leads are:
Banks and Credit Unions Web Designers, Web Hosting and SEO Companies Franchisers Trade Associations Business Opportunity and Direct Marketing Companies Telemarketing Companies Trade Show Promoters Chambers of Commerce and Networking Groups Advertisers, Magazine Publishers, Yellow Pages Fulfillment Centers Government Agencies
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Existing Customers:
“Don’t make the enormous mistake of not keeping in touch with your customers after the sale. Customers who are treated well will often feel obligated to refer you other customers. If you sweeten the deal by throwing in a few bucks or a gift as a reward for sending you the business many of them will go out of their way to send you referrals.” Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. Traditional Marketing Methods:
Promote with your own advertising campaign. Remember to have all ads approved in writing before you use them. Design the ads you want and we'll advise you how to keep them compliant.
Types of advertising might include:
Direct mail Magazine and newspaper ads Specialized publications Yellow Pages Flyers Search Engines Web sites- Internet Ads Email Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. USMS Marketing:
Vertical Marketing Brochures- show combined solutions for vertical markets such as restaurants, fast food, medical and dental, retail, and e-commerce, etc. Show that USMS is concerned with the overall well being and needs of our clients.
USMS Web Site- has many helpful items including reports you can print out and provide to prospects.
USMS Service Guarantee- this document has closed many sales and our commitment to providing great service and helping merchants save money. Have several color copies with you at all times.
Miscellaneous- customer satisfaction letters, product sheets, reports and other data available on the sales agent portion of the web site.
Prospecting

© 2013 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved.
©2007 U.S. Merchant Systems. All rights reserved. USMS Marketing:
USMS Leads:
The company generates many leads from various sources including telemarketing, direct mail, web leads, ads and referrals.
When you receive a company lead, keep in mind that a lot has gone into generating it. You saved a significant amount of time and energy required to source a lead.
Due to the cost of generating leads, the company has specific policies that must be adhered to for working and reporting status on leads. To receive leads, you must follow these policies and produce a reasonable amount of sales from them. Prospecting
